awd_titl_txt: Solution of Sparse High-Dimensional Linear Inverse problems with  Application to Analysis of Dynamic Contrast Enhanced Imaging  Data
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

por.por_cntn:
The present proposal is motivated by analysis of Dynamic Contrast Enhanced (DCE) imaging  data.  DCE imaging  provides a non-invasive measure of tumor angiogenesis and has great potential for cancer detection and characterization. It offers an in vivo tool for the evaluation and optimization of new therapeutic strategies as well as for longitudinal evaluation of therapeutic impacts of anti-angiogenic treatments. The difficulties in deciphering  the information provided by those imaging technique stem from  the high level of noise, insufficient number of measurements due to desire to limit the patients' exposure to radiation and to the fact that recovery of the useful information relies on solutions of   inverse ill-posed problems which are intrinsically  very unstable. The diagram of a DCE-CT experiment is presented on Figure 1.

The current project presents an integral effort of merging applications and theory. Mathematically, the problem reduces to solution of a noisy version of a Laplace convolution equation based on discrete measurements. One of the significant outcomes of the project is that we successfully adopted application of sparse representations via overcomplete dictionaries to solution of  linear inverse problems. In particular, we provided theoretical background  and MatLab software for solution of such problems. Figures 2  presents observations and an estimator of a tissue enhancements for one of the patients in the REMISCAN studies. In spite of very low number of observations (n = 23),  we constructed a theoretically justified estimator of the function of interest  for one of the tissues on the basis of CT scan (Figure 3). We furthermore extended our approach to studying all voxels in the area of interest simultaneously using functional data analysis approach. Figures 4, 5 and 6 present the estimated temporal-spatial function of interest 34, 95 and 275 seconds after the contrast agent was injected. The theoretical findings and the software will help medical evaluation and prognosis for cancer patients especially for tumors located in  hard to reach areas such as kidneys.

The overall results of the NSF funding consist of 11 papers (including 3 papers in the Annals of Statistics and one paper in the Journal of the Royal Statistical Society), CRAN package, software available on the PI’s website, 12 conference or colloquium talks and various educational and outreach activities. In particular, the grant provided training to my graduate students (2 M.S. students graduated and 3 Ph.D. students are writing their theses), facilitated my learning and introduction of three special topics graduate courses that, in turn, contributed to training not only to students in Mathematics department but also in Statistics, Physics (Astronomy) and Computer Science. NSF funding also released my time and allowed me to carry out various outreach activities like directing a high school Science Fair project or co-advising a Ph.D. student in Department of Computer Science.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2017
Modified by: Marianna Pensky

The present proposal is motivated by analysis of Dynamic Contrast Enhanced (DCE) imaging  data.  DCE imaging  provides a non-invasive measure of tumor angiogenesis and has great potential for cancer detection and characterization. It offers an in vivo tool for the evaluation and optimization of new therapeutic strategies as well as for longitudinal evaluation of therapeutic impacts of anti-angiogenic treatments. The difficulties in deciphering  the information provided by those imaging technique stem from  the high level of noise, insufficient number of measurements due to desire to limit the patients' exposure to radiation and to the fact that recovery of the useful information relies on solutions of   inverse ill-posed problems which are intrinsically  very unstable. The diagram of a DCE-CT experiment is presented on Figure 1.

The current project presents an integral effort of merging applications and theory. Mathematically, the problem reduces to solution of a noisy version of a Laplace convolution equation based on discrete measurements. One of the significant outcomes of the project is that we successfully adopted application of sparse representations via overcomplete dictionaries to solution of  linear inverse problems. In particular, we provided theoretical background  and MatLab software for solution of such problems. Figures 2  presents observations and an estimator of a tissue enhancements for one of the patients in the REMISCAN studies. In spite of very low number of observations (n = 23),  we constructed a theoretically justified estimator of the function of interest  for one of the tissues on the basis of CT scan (Figure 3). We furthermore extended our approach to studying all voxels in the area of interest simultaneously using functional data analysis approach. Figures 4, 5 and 6 present the estimated temporal-spatial function of interest 34, 95 and 275 seconds after the contrast agent was injected. The theoretical findings and the software will help medical evaluation and prognosis for cancer patients especially for tumors located in  hard to reach areas such as kidneys.

The overall results of the NSF funding consist of 11 papers (including 3 papers in the Annals of Statistics and one paper in the Journal of the Royal Statistical Society), CRAN package, software available on the PI?s website, 12 conference or colloquium talks and various educational and outreach activities. In particular, the grant provided training to my graduate students (2 M.S. students graduated and 3 Ph.D. students are writing their theses), facilitated my learning and introduction of three special topics graduate courses that, in turn, contributed to training not only to students in Mathematics department but also in Statistics, Physics (Astronomy) and Computer Science. NSF funding also released my time and allowed me to carry out various outreach activities like directing a high school Science Fair project or co-advising a Ph.D. student in Department of Computer Science.
